Antipsychotics'' are substances whose common property is an ''antagonistic'' action on D2 dopamine receptors.

A distinction is made between :

* older drugs (typical or first-generation neuroleptics or antipsychotics)
* more recent compounds (atypical or second-generation antipsychotics) with a better neurological safety profile (extrapyramidal syndrome), but with a higher risk of adverse metabolic effects.
The main "first-generation" antipsychotics used in practice are :

* Chlorpromazine,
* Cyamemazine
* Alimemazine
* Levomepromazine
* Haloperidol
* Loxapine

The main "second-generation" antipsychotics used in practice are :

* Amisulpride,
* Olanzapine
* Clozapine
* Quetiapine
* Risperidone
* Paliperidone,
* Aripiprazole.

question.title: What is the main distinction between typical and atypical antipsychotics?
question.description: A question about the classification of antipsychotics

option_a.title: Typical antipsychotics are more effective and have a better safety profile than atypical antipsychotics
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option about the relative effectiveness and safety of typical and atypical antipsychotics

option_b.title: Atypical antipsychotics have a higher risk of extrapyramidal syndrome than typical antipsychotics
option_b.description: A plausible but incorrect option about the risk of extrapyramidal syndrome associated with typical and atypical antipsychotics

option_c.title: Typical antipsychotics are more commonly used in practice than atypical antipsychotics
option_c.description: A plausible but incorrect option about the relative prevalence of typical and atypical antipsychotics in clinical practice

option_d.title: Atypical antipsychotics have a better neurological safety profile and a lower risk of adverse metabolic effects than typical antipsychotics
option_d.description: The correct option that accurately describes the main distinction between typical and atypical antipsychotics
